title: JCap reports lack 'smoking gun', says bearish analyst
text:
Mr James has a price target of $8.10 on the company's shares, which last traded at $26.30 before trading was halted on Monday for the second time in three trading days.

The two reports released by JCap make a range of allegations against WiseTech, including that it has utilised an audit loophole to inflate its revenue, disguised the amount of organic revenue versus acquired revenue, and made a suite of poor acquisitions to maintain the appearance of a high-growth company.

WiseTech is yet to respond to the claims in the second report, but is expected to on Wednesday morning.

In only a few hours of trading last Thursday and on Monday, WiseTech shares fell almost 21 per cent as a result of the reports' claims.

Mr James, whose price target is almost $17 below the next lowest analyst listed on Bloomberg, was also critical of JCap's second report, which focused on WiseTech's aggressive acquisition strategy and customer retention.

"We're not particularly surprised that such a rapid expansion may have experienced a variety of issues, but this doesn't necessarily undermine the long-term global expansion strategy of the company," he said.

Advertisement

"Each acquisition has been small relative to the group and management have been transparent about the typically low profits generated by these firms.

"The aim of the acquisition strategy has been to quickly establish local expertise and clients in new geographies, rather than earnings per share accretion (EPS), and to create a global framework from which to expand."

The critique from Mr James follows similar ones from Evans and Partners' Paul Mason and Blue Ocean Equities' Stuart Turner.

Last week Mr Turner called JCap's claims "spurious and nonsense", saying the company was "not faking anything, its cash conversion is fine. We have no issues with it whatsoever."

'Not too impressed'

Speaking to The Australian Financial Review, Mr James said there was definitely a need for the type of research reports produced by JCap, saying it can be tough for many local analysts to be critical of companies because of conflicting interests within sell-side firms.

He also said he had pushed the company to provide more disclosure on its pricing model. Morningstar also uses a lower growth rate in its models than other analysts – a 13 per cent compound annual revenue growth (CAGR) and an EPS CAGR 18 per cent over the next decade.

But, he said there were too many aspects of the JCap report on WiseTech that were questionable and undermined its research, making it unconvincing and raising concerns that it was designed to bring the share price down without being based on facts.

"I'm not too impressed and I have some concerns that JCap's strategy is too long in the tooth and it's looking for stuff where there isn't much to find," he said.

"I've always been a big fan of this kind of research ... [but] a lot of arguments in the report are around the edges, which can have a big impact if the share price is extremely stressed to start with.

"JCap has probably made some good points, but they haven't come out with something groundbreaking or shown that WiseTech is a fraud."
description: Morningstar's Gareth James has the lowest target price on WiseTech of $8.10 of all the analysts on Bloomberg, but he did not find the JCap reports convincing.
